text:
Parents, siblings, partners,
faculty and staff, and my fellow

graduates of the class
of 2024, good afternoon.
[APPLAUSE]

Tomorrow we celebrate
your achievements,

but today we celebrate the
spirit, heart, and resilience
that brought you here.

Today is day 637, and today
marks yet another milestone
in our journey together.

A milestone that could not
have been achieved without each

and every one of you here in the
audience and those not present.

So we not only welcome
you, but also thank you

for supporting, some of
you maybe even financing,
the class of 2024.

Together, this class has endured
a lot over the past two years.

While it's easy to presume
that HBS believes that business

and life's lessons are best
taught through the case method,

much of what I have learned
over the past two years

occurred outside
of the classroom.

During our time here,
the world has been
a stage for profound trials.

The conflict in the Middle
East has reminded us

of the delicate threads
that hold peace together

and the consequences of discord
when those threads unravel.

The conflict has echoed through
our campuses and communities,

stirring debates, creating
divides, and challenging

our judgments of justice,
empathy, and humanity.

It has invited feelings
of hopelessness.
It has filled us with rage.

And it has downright made us
question what the right thing

to say is and the weight
that those words may carry.

We may not agree on everything,
and that is certainly

not the goal, but we owe
it to this community,

and certainly to one another,
to build a network that

can engage in open,
thought-provoking,

and civil dialogue,
regardless of the complexity

or the difficulty of the
crises that we find ourselves
in the midst of.

Within the classroom,
we debated everything

from what belongs where
on a financial accounting

ledger to the life changing
implications of generative AI,
both positive and negative.

We learned not only about,
but from each other.

Every single case discussion
was uniquely colored

with that section's
interpretations,

lived experiences,
perceptions, and insights.

We may not remember every
comment that we've ever made.

I can tell you I
definitely do not.

But throughout the course
of these discussions,

we have built business judgment
and intuition, the ability

to run through
multiple scenarios,

and critically think about
strategic consequences.

Business tradeoffs,
ethical dilemmas,

and so many other dimensions
of decision-making

are the muscles we have
stretched and grown
over the past two years.

This is what we will carry
forward with us into the world

as we face our own set
of challenges in our path
to making a difference.

As we look toward the
next chapter of our lives,

uncertainty is an
inevitable footnote.

From geopolitical strife
to technological upheaval,

each note, though
daunting, is a call

to action, an opportunity to
create harmony out of chaos,
and opportunity as a privilege.

As I look toward what I
hope to do with this degree,

I am reminded of a dinner
table question my friend posed
a few weeks ago.

Do you think a Harvard degree
would be worth anything
in like 20 years?

Now, despite being terrible
dinner table conversation,

it made me realize that
the answer to that question

hinges on our commitment to the
future of the HBS community.

Let us pledge to be there
for one another in the years
to come.

Our shared experience
over the past two years

not only connects
us to each other,

but also to the alumni
that came before us

and the students that
will come after us.

Let us extend that
pledge to anyone

that seeks our small
acts of kindness,

because that is how the brand of
Harvard Business School that we

have so often questioned in
the past two years will endure.

Let us remember that
the ties that we've

knotted here, loose or tight,
can be the net that catches you

in time of need,
because sometimes it

is the randomness
of our networks
that make all the difference.

I witnessed section mates, who
knew each other only for two

months, support each other
through loss of loved ones.

I witnessed peers from
different business backgrounds

encourage each other through
crushing recruiting letdowns

and end up championing
their career search process.

I witnessed friends
help each other heal

from serious physical injuries,
heartbreak, and mental health
issues.

Simply put, I witnessed
care extended beyond reason,
even beyond my own experiences.

One of our professors, an HBS
alumnus from the class of 1996,

told us the story how
one of his section mates

ended up creating a
medical device that

could improve and prolong
another section mate's life
as he battled ALS.

This community
has not yet failed

to exemplify resilience and
compassion in time of need.

And as we leave this campus,
I hold you, class of 2024,

accountable to keep
that strength going.

Graduates, our time
together on campus

is about to come to an end,
but our time together as alumni
is only just beginning.

We have reunions
to look forward to,

raising committed
capital vehicles

with section mate,
Michael Jordan Capital,

and of course, donation requests
from HBS, which I believe

are scheduled to go out
sometime tomorrow maybe.

But during the insecurities and
anxieties that future presents,

look back at your achievements
here and the achievements

that brought you here,
not to pat yourselves

on your back for them, but
rather to remind yourselves

of the spirit, heart, and
resilience that enabled them.

Channel those values as you
seek to achieve further.

What we have been able
to accomplish together

over the past two
years would not

have been possible without
the support and commitment

of the diverse fabric of
individuals that weave together

the community that is
Harvard Business School.

Thank you to Dean Datar,
Jana, Matt, Barbara, Mike,

Ellen, and each and every one of
you for believing in us to lead

and serve this vibrant
community of leaders

who will make a
difference in this world.

And of course, we could
not have delivered for you

all without the support of our
Student Association Cabinet,

Senate and broader
leadership team,

RCs and ECs who have committed
so much of their time and effort

at HBS to serve and build
this holistic experience.

If you were a part of
the Student Association,

please stand up,
those in the crowd.
Round of applause.
[APPLAUSE]
Thank you.

We would also be remiss not to
recognize all 11 of our section

presidents and
leadership teams who

crafted 11 unique but
coherent stories that

make the class of
2024 what it is today.

It is the students, past,
present, and future,

that make Harvard Business
School the institution

that it is, and
these individuals
exemplify that notion.

Personally, I would like to
express thanks to my greatest
supporters, [SPEAKING KOREAN].
[APPLAUSE]

And I would like to express
my gratitude to my village,

without whom I would
not be here today.

To my father Bala, my mother
Lakshmi, my brother Sevanthi,

my sister Samyuktha, and little
Adya, and friends far and near,
thank you.
[APPLAUSE]

Graduates, you have waited
637 days for this moment,

and the time has
finally arrived.

Congratulations to
the class of 2024.
We made it!
[APPLAUSE]
